Hero’s Adventure is not just a story—it’s a journey through the soul of a world that feels ancient, poetic, and alive. The lands you travel are vast and boundless, filled with hidden sects, rival clans, and wandering heroes each chasing their own meaning. The air hums with the quiet power of cultivation, the philosophy of growth and balance shaping every path you take. It is a world that invites you not to follow, but to choose—to craft your own legend within its living, breathing expanse.

[h2]Freedom & Choice: The Essence of Adventure[/h2]
What truly defines Hero’s Adventure is its boundless freedom. Every decision branches into a new story, every choice ripples through your fate. You can walk the path of a righteous sect disciple, a cunning wanderer, a loyal companion—or something entirely your own. Romance, rivalry, friendship, betrayal—each is yours to shape. [h2]Gameplay & Variety: Mastery through Expression[/h2]

The freedom of combat mirrors the freedom of choice; whether you wield a swift sword or a heavy staff, each style feels distinct and rewarding. The replay value is immense—not just because of mechanics, but because you are different every time you return.

[h2]Community & Growth: A Journey Shared[/h2]
Though the English translation stumbles at times, the heart of the story still shines through—and it grows stronger every day, thanks to passionate fans and volunteer translators. The community surrounding the game is a reflection of its world: warm, dedicated, and eager to help new travelers find their way. Detailed guides, advice, and genuine support make this adventure feel like a shared pilgrimage rather than a solitary one.

[h2]Final Reflection: A Cultivation of the Spirit[/h2]
Hero’s Adventure: Road to Passion is not merely played—it is lived. It embodies the essence of the cultivation genre: perseverance, choice, transformation. In its vastness, you find freedom; in its challenges, purpose. Despite its imperfections, it stands as one of the most open, personal, and heartfelt RPGs.

For those who seek meaning, growth, and a world that rewards curiosity, this is a journey worth taking—a path where passion truly becomes destiny.

Reading through the other comments, I noticed a lot of them mentioning the bad translation, and even when you start the game, a pop-up message will inform you to refund the game within 2 hours because of it. But after investing around 11 hours into the game, I can say the translation is not much of an issue. Only a few times did I see non translated Chinese characters in the text and the grammar seems also fine overall. But keep in mind, that the English translation is a community project.

On the other hand, the localization is a big issue. The game is set in the distant past, which is closer to fantasy and fiction than reality. Especially as there is close to no recorded history of that time period, which may or may not be related to the cultural revolution where books and their owners were relocated en masse into the “shadow realm.”
Anyhow, to immerse the player, the decision was made to also use the old Chinese terms for the time, day, and money. For example, the day was divided into the twelve zodiacs, and a short tutorial message will inform you about the details when you start a playthrough, but I forgot almost everything shortly after. Reading through the other comments, I noticed a lot of them mentioning the bad translation, and even when you start the game, a pop-up message will inform you to refund the game within 2 hours because of it. But after investing around 11 hours into the game, I can say the translation is not much of an issue. Only a few times did I see non translated Chinese characters in the text and the grammar seems also fine overall. But keep in mind, that the English translation is a community project.

On the other hand, the localization is a big issue. The game is set in the distant past, which is closer to fantasy and fiction than reality. Especially as there is close to no recorded history of that time period, which may or may not be related to the cultural revolution where books and their owners were relocated en masse into the “shadow realm.”
Anyhow, to immerse the player, the decision was made to also use the old Chinese terms for the time, day, and money. For example, the day was divided into the twelve zodiacs, and a short tutorial message will inform you about the details when you start a playthrough, but I forgot almost everything shortly after. Resulting in the situation that I can only estimate the current in-game time and have no idea how much money I have (bigger numbers are better).

You will also have to get used to cheat sheets and/or look up guides if you want to have an efficient playthrough, as the game is set up to be played many times. There is also some kind of inheritance system in place for skills and traits, but I am not far enough to speak about it. You will regularly encounter events that will “fail” or play out non-optimally, as you lack the skills or resources to influence them in any way.

I chose to play this game blind and did not read any guides, only looked up the answers for some riddles, and had a few issues due to “grind.” At first I filled out my party with every NPC I could, but failed to notice that there are several kinds of XP, engagement, and skill use. Engagement XP levels you up and increases your health and mana (I think). But skills only level with use, so if you have a big party, the characters have less chance to use them. Often your player character is forced to engage in solo fights, which can be challenging if your protagonist is “underleveled.” To mitigate, I reduced my party to 3 characters max, which helped a lot. But the combat turned tedious as a result, especially with many enemies. Thankfully there is an auto-combat option and a combat speed setting; unfortunately, changing the speed to 2x or 4x did nothing. So I set the game to auto-combat and just tabbed out and browsed Reddit or something, only to check in every few minutes to see if the combat was resolved. But then I asked myself why play the game at all, if I am forced to ignore a major part of it.

There are also many mods in the Steam Workshop, but seemingly 99% of those are in Chinese, and they will disable the inheritance system and achievements. So I also did not bother wiuth them as well.

In summary, this is a very decent indie game, which will be greatly enjoyed by the target demographic. But to me it is too flawed to recommend it.

Reading through the other comments, I noticed a lot of them mentioning the bad translation, and even when you start the game, a pop-up message will inform you to refund the game within 2 hours because of it. But after investing around 11 hours into the game, I can say the translation is not much of an issue. Only a few times did I see non translated Chinese characters in the text and the grammar seems also fine overall. But keep in mind, that the English translation is a community project.

On the other hand, the localization is a big issue. The game is set in the distant past, which is closer to fantasy and fiction than reality. Especially as there is close to no recorded history of that time period, which may or may not be related to the cultural revolution where books and their owners were relocated en masse into the “shadow realm.”
Anyhow, to immerse the player, the decision was made to also use the old Chinese terms for the time, day, and money. For example, the day was divided into the twelve zodiacs, and a short tutorial message will inform you about the details when you start a playthrough, but I forgot almost everything shortly after. Resulting in the situation that I can only estimate the current in-game time and have no idea how much money I have (bigger numbers are better).

You will also have to get used to cheat sheets and/or look up guides if you want to have an efficient playthrough, as the game is set up to be played many times. There is also some kind of inheritance system in place for skills and traits, but I am not far enough to speak about it. You will regularly encounter events that will “fail” or play out non-optimally, as you lack the skills or resources to influence them in any way.

I chose to play this game blind and did not read any guides, only looked up the answers for some riddles, and had a few issues due to “grind.” At first I filled out my party with every NPC I could, but failed to notice that there are several kinds of XP, engagement, and skill use. Engagement XP levels you up and increases your health and mana (I think). But skills only level with use, so if you have a big party, the characters have less chance to use them. Often your player character is forced to engage in solo fights, which can be challenging if your protagonist is “underleveled.” To mitigate, I reduced my party to 3 characters max, which helped a lot. But the combat turned tedious as a result, especially with many enemies. Thankfully there is an auto-combat option and a combat speed setting; unfortunately, changing the speed to 2x or 4x did nothing. So I set the game to auto-combat and just tabbed out and browsed Reddit or something, only to check in every few minutes to see if the combat was resolved. But then I asked myself why play the game at all, if I am forced to ignore a major part of it.

There are also many mods in the Steam Workshop, but seemingly 99% of those are in Chinese, and they will disable the inheritance system and achievements. So I also did not bother wiuth them as well.

In summary, this is a very decent indie game, which will be greatly enjoyed by the target demographic. But to me it is too flawed to recommend it.
